segment.source: Configure MBAM to escrow the TPM and store OwnerAuth passwords
segment.target: Configure MBAM to escrow the TPM and store OwnerAuth passwords

segment.source: Depending on its configuration, the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) will lock itself in certain situations ─ such as when too many incorrect passwords are entered ─ and can remain locked for a period of time.
segment.target: Depending on its configuration, the Trusted Platform Module (TPM) will lock itself in certain situations ─ such as when too many incorrect passwords are entered ─ and can remain locked for a period of time.

segment.source: During TPM lockout, BitLocker cannot access the encryption keys to perform unlock or decryption operations, requiring the user to enter their BitLocker recovery key to access the operating system drive.
segment.target: During TPM lockout, BitLocker cannot access the encryption keys to perform unlock or decryption operations, requiring the user to enter their BitLocker recovery key to access the operating system drive.

segment.source: To reset TPM lockout, you must provide the TPM OwnerAuth password.
segment.target: To reset TPM lockout, you must provide the TPM OwnerAuth password.

segment.source: MBAM can store the TPM OwnerAuth password in the MBAM database if it owns the TPM or if it escrows the password.
segment.target: MBAM can store the TPM OwnerAuth password in the MBAM database if it owns the TPM or if it escrows the password.

segment.source: OwnerAuth passwords are then easily accessible on the Administration and Monitoring Website when you must recover from a TPM lockout, eliminating the need to wait for the lockout to resolve on its own.
segment.target: OwnerAuth passwords are then easily accessible on the Administration and Monitoring Website when you must recover from a TPM lockout, eliminating the need to wait for the lockout to resolve on its own.

segment.source: Configure MBAM to automatically unlock the TPM after a lockout
segment.target: Configure MBAM to automatically unlock the TPM after a lockout

segment.source: You can configure MBAM 2.5 SP1 to automatically unlock the TPM in case of a lockout.
segment.target: You can configure MBAM 2.5 SP1 to automatically unlock the TPM in case of a lockout.

segment.source: If TPM lockout auto reset is enabled, MBAM can detect that a user is locked out and then get the OwnerAuth password from the MBAM database to automatically unlock the TPM for the user.
segment.target: If TPM lockout auto reset is enabled, MBAM can detect that a user is locked out and then get the OwnerAuth password from the MBAM database to automatically unlock the TPM for the user.

segment.source: TPM lockout auto reset is only available if the OS recovery key for that computer was retrieved by using the Self Service Portal or the Administration and Monitoring Website.
segment.target: TPM lockout auto reset is only available if the OS recovery key for that computer was retrieved by using the Self Service Portal or the Administration and Monitoring Website.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: To enable TPM lockout auto reset, you must configure this feature on both the server side and in Group Policy on the client side.
segment.target: To enable TPM lockout auto reset, you must configure this feature on both the server side and in Group Policy on the client side.

segment.source: To enable TPM lockout auto reset on the client side, configure the Group Policy setting "Configure TPM lockout auto reset" located at Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsMDOP MBAMClient Management.
segment.target: To enable TPM lockout auto reset on the client side, configure the Group Policy setting "Configure TPM lockout auto reset" located at Computer ConfigurationAdministrative TemplatesWindows ComponentsMDOP MBAMClient Management.

segment.source: To enable TPM lockout auto reset on the server side, you can check "Enable TPM lockout auto reset" in the MBAM Server Configuration wizard during setup.
segment.target: To enable TPM lockout auto reset on the server side, you can check "Enable TPM lockout auto reset" in the MBAM Server Configuration wizard during setup.

segment.source: You can also enable TPM lockout auto reset in PowerShell by specifying the "-TPM lockout auto reset" switch while enabling the agent service web component.
segment.target: You can also enable TPM lockout auto reset in PowerShell by specifying the "-TPM lockout auto reset" switch while enabling the agent service web component.

segment.source: After a user enters the BitLocker recovery key they obtained from the Self Service Portal or the Administration and Monitoring Website, the MBAM agent will determine if the TPM is locked out.
segment.target: After a user enters the BitLocker recovery key they obtained from the Self Service Portal or the Administration and Monitoring Website, the MBAM agent will determine if the TPM is locked out.

segment.source: If it is locked out, it will attempt to retrieve the TPM OwnerAuth for the computer from the MBAM database.
segment.target: If it is locked out, it will attempt to retrieve the TPM OwnerAuth for the computer from the MBAM database.

segment.source: If the TPM OwnerAuth is successfully retrieved, it will be used to unlock the TPM.
segment.target: If the TPM OwnerAuth is successfully retrieved, it will be used to unlock the TPM.

segment.source: Unlocking the TPM makes the TPM fully functional and the user will not be forced to enter the recovery password during subsequent reboots from a TPM lockout.
segment.target: Unlocking the TPM makes the TPM fully functional and the user will not be forced to enter the recovery password during subsequent reboots from a TPM lockout.

segment.source: TPM lockout auto reset is disabled by default.
segment.target: TPM lockout auto reset is disabled by default.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: TPM lockout auto reset is only supported on computers running TPM version 1.2.
segment.target: TPM lockout auto reset is only supported on computers running TPM version 1.2.

segment.source: TPM 2.0 provides built-in lockout auto reset functionality.
segment.target: TPM 2.0 provides built-in lockout auto reset functionality.

segment.source: Review MBAM database TDE considerations
segment.target: Review MBAM database TDE considerations

segment.source: The transparent data encryption (TDE) feature that is available in SQL Server is an optional installation for the database instances that will host the MBAM database features.
segment.target: The transparent data encryption (TDE) feature that is available in SQL Server is an optional installation for the database instances that will host the MBAM database features.

segment.source: With TDE, you can perform real-time, full database-level encryption.
segment.target: With TDE, you can perform real-time, full database-level encryption.

segment.source: TDE is the optimal choice for bulk encryption to meet regulatory compliance or corporate data security standards.
segment.target: TDE is the optimal choice for bulk encryption to meet regulatory compliance or corporate data security standards.

segment.source: TDE works at the file level, which is similar to two Windows features: the Encrypting File System (EFS) and BitLocker Drive Encryption.
segment.target: TDE works at the file level, which is similar to two Windows features: the Encrypting File System (EFS) and BitLocker Drive Encryption.

segment.source: Both features also encrypt data on the hard drive.
segment.target: Both features also encrypt data on the hard drive.

segment.source: TDE does not replace cell-level encryption, EFS, or BitLocker.
segment.target: TDE does not replace cell-level encryption, EFS, or BitLocker.

segment.source: When TDE is enabled on a database, all backups are encrypted.
segment.target: When TDE is enabled on a database, all backups are encrypted.

segment.source: Thus, special care must be taken to ensure that the certificate that was used to protect the database encryption key is backed up and maintained with the database backup.
segment.target: Thus, special care must be taken to ensure that the certificate that was used to protect the database encryption key is backed up and maintained with the database backup.

segment.source: If this certificate (or certificates) is lost, the data will be unreadable.
segment.target: If this certificate (or certificates) is lost, the data will be unreadable.

segment.source: Back up the certificate with the database.
segment.target: Back up the certificate with the database.

segment.source: Each certificate backup should have two files.
segment.target: Each certificate backup should have two files.

segment.source: Both of these files should be archived.
segment.target: Both of these files should be archived.

segment.source: Ideally for security, they should be backed up separately from the database backup file.
segment.target: Ideally for security, they should be backed up separately from the database backup file.

segment.source: You can alternatively consider using the extensible key management (EKM) feature (see Extensible Key Management) for storage and maintenance of keys that are used for TDE.
segment.target: You can alternatively consider using the extensible key management (EKM) feature (see Extensible Key Management) for storage and maintenance of keys that are used for TDE.

segment.source: Understand the security risks.
segment.target: Understand the security risks.

segment.source: The most serious risk when you use Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring is that its functionality could be compromised by an unauthorized user who could then reconfigure BitLocker Drive Encryption and gain BitLocker encryption key data on MBAM Clients.
segment.target: The most serious risk when you use Microsoft BitLocker Administration and Monitoring is that its functionality could be compromised by an unauthorized user who could then reconfigure BitLocker Drive Encryption and gain BitLocker encryption key data on MBAM Clients.

segment.source: However, the loss of MBAM functionality for a short period of time, due to a denial-of-service attack, does not generally have a catastrophic impact, unlike, for example, losing e-mail or network communications, or power.

segment.source: Physically secure your computers.
segment.target: Physically secure your computers.

segment.source: There is no security without physical security.
segment.target: There is no security without physical security.

segment.source: An attacker who gets physical access to an MBAM Server could potentially use it to attack the entire client base.
segment.target: An attacker who gets physical access to an MBAM Server could potentially use it to attack the entire client base.

segment.source: All potential physical attacks must be considered high risk and mitigated appropriately.
segment.target: All potential physical attacks must be considered high risk and mitigated appropriately.

segment.source: MBAM Servers should be stored in a secure server room with controlled access.
segment.target: MBAM Servers should be stored in a secure server room with controlled access.

segment.source: Secure these computers when administrators are not physically present by having the operating system lock the computer, or by using a secured screen saver.
segment.target: Secure these computers when administrators are not physically present by having the operating system lock the computer, or by using a secured screen saver.

segment.source: Apply the most recent security updates to all computers.
segment.target: Apply the most recent security updates to all computers.

segment.source: Stay informed about new updates for Windows operating systems, SQL Server, and MBAM by subscribing to the Security Notification service at the Security TechCenter.
segment.target: Stay informed about new updates for Windows operating systems, SQL Server, and MBAM by subscribing to the Security Notification service at the Security TechCenter.

segment.source: Always use strong passwords with 15 or more characters for all MBAM administrator accounts.
segment.target: Always use strong passwords with 15 or more characters for all MBAM administrator accounts.

segment.source: Never use blank passwords.
segment.target: Never use blank passwords.
